metadata.title: Secure Software Development Attestation Form Requirements

groups.id: 4e(i)
groups.title: The software was developed and built in secure environments

controls.title: Separate and protect each environment involved in developing and building software
Regularly logging, monitoring, and auditing trust relationships used for authorization and access to any software development and build environments, andamong components within each environment
Enforcing multi-factor authentication and conditional access across the environments relevant to developing and building software in a manner that minimizes security risk
Taking consistent and reasonable steps to document, as well as minimize use or inclusion of software products that create undue risk, within the environments used to develop and build software
Encrypting sensitive data, such as credentials, to the extent practicable and based on risk
Implementing defensive cyber security practices, including continuous monitoring of operations and alerts and, as necessary, responding to suspected and confirmed cyber incidents

groups.id: 4e(iii)
groups.title: The software producer has made a good-faith effort to maintain trusted source code supply chains by:

controls.title: Employing automated tools or comparable processes
Establishing a process that includes reasonable steps to address the security of third-party components and manage related vulnerabilities

groups.id: 4e(iv)
groups.title: The software producer employed automated tools or comparable processes that check for security vulnerabilities

controls.title: The software producer ensured these processes operate on an ongoing basis and, at a minimum, prior to product, version, or update releases
The software producer has a policy or process to address discovered security vulnerabilities prior to product release
The software producer operates a vulnerability disclosure program and accepts, reviews, and addresses disclosed software vulnerabilities in a timely fashion

groups.id: 4e(vi)
groups.title: Provenance data maintenance

controls.title: The software producer maintains provenance data for internal and third-party code incorporated into the software

groups.title: PO_1
groups.id: Define Security Requirements for Software Development

controls.title: Identify and document all security requirements for the organization’s software development infrastructures and processes, and maintain the requirements over time.

props.name: SCFPSSD
props.value: Planning the Implementation and Deployment of Secure Development Practices

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Define policies for securing software development infrastructures and their components, including development endpoints, throughout the SDLC and maintaining that security.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Define policies for securing software development processes throughout the SDLC and maintaining that security, including for open-source and other third-party software components utilized by software being developed.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_1.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Review and update security requirements at least annually, or sooner if there are new requirements from internal or external sources, or a major security incident targeting software development infrastructure has occurred.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_1.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Educate affected individuals on impending changes to requirements.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_1.

controls.title: Identify and document all security requirements for organization-developed software to meet, and maintain the requirements over time.

props.name: BSAFSS
props.value: SC.1-1, SC.2, PD.1-1, PD.1-2, PD.1-3, PD.2-2, SI, PA, CS, AA, LO, EE

props.name: OWASPSAMM
props.value: PC1-A, PC1-B, PC2-A, PC3-A, SR1-A, SR1-B, SR2-B, SA1-B, IR1-A

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Define policies that specify risk-based software architecture and design requirements, such as making code modular to facilitate code reuse and updates; isolating security components from other components during execution; avoiding undocumented commands and settings; and providing features that will aid software acquirers with the secure deployment, operation, and maintenance of the software.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_2.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Define policies that specify the security requirements for the organization’s software, and verify compliance at key points in the SDLC (e.g., classes of software flaws verified by gates, responses to vulnerabilities discovered in released software).
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_2.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Analyze the risk of applicable technology stacks (e.g., languages, environments, deployment models), and recommend or require the use of stacks that will reduce risk compared to others.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_2.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Define policies that specify what needs to be archived for each software release (e.g., code, package files, third-party libraries, documentation, data inventory) and how long it needs to be retained based on the SDLC model, software end-of-life, and other factors.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_2.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Ensure that policies cover the entire software life cycle, including notifying users of the impending end of software support and the date of software end-of-life.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_2.

parts.name: Example 6
parts.title: Review all security requirements at least annually, or sooner if there are new requirements from internal or external sources, a major vulnerability is discovered in released software, or a major security incident targeting organization-developed software has occurred.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_2.

parts.name: Example 7
parts.title: Establish and follow processes for handling requirement exception requests, including periodic reviews of all approved exceptions.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_2.

controls.title: Communicate requirements to all third parties who will provide commercial software components to the organization for reuse by the organization’s own software. [Formerly PW.3.1]

props.name: SCAGILE
props.value: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 8

props.name: SCFPSSD
props.value: Manage Security Risk Inherent in the Use of Third-Party Components

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Define a core set of security requirements for software components, and include it in acquisition documents, software contracts, and other agreements with third parties.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_3.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Define security-related criteria for selecting software; the criteria can include the third party’s vulnerability disclosure program and product security incident response capabilities or the third party’s adherence to organization-defined practices.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_3.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Require third parties to attest that their software complies with the organization’s security requirements.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_3.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Require third parties to provide provenance data and integrity verification mechanisms for all components of their software.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_3.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Establish and follow processes to address risk when there are security requirements that third-party software components to be acquired do not meet; this should include periodic reviews of all approved exceptions to requirements.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_1_3.

groups.title: PO_2
groups.id: Implement Roles and Responsibilities

controls.title: Create new roles and alter responsibilities for existing roles as needed to encompass all parts of the SDLC. Periodically review and maintain the defined roles and responsibilities, updating them as needed.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Define SDLC-related roles and responsibilities for all members of the software development team.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Integrate the security roles into the software development team.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_1.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Define roles and responsibilities for cybersecurity staff, security champions, project managers and leads, senior management, software developers, software testers, software assurance leads and staff, product owners, operations and platform engineers, and others involved in the SDLC.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_1.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Conduct an annual review of all roles and responsibilities.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_1.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Educate affected individuals on impending changes to roles and responsibilities, and confirm that the individuals understand the changes and agree to follow them.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_1.

parts.name: Example 6
parts.title: Implement and use tools and processes to promote communication and engagement among individuals with SDLC-related roles and responsibilities, such as creating messaging channels for team discussions.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_1.

parts.name: Example 7
parts.title: Designate a group of individuals or a team as the code owner for each project.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_1.

controls.title: Provide role-based training for all personnel with responsibilities that contribute to secure development. Periodically review personnel proficiency and role-based training, and update the training as needed.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Document the desired outcomes of training for each role.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_2.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Define the type of training or curriculum required to achieve the desired outcome for each role.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_2.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Create a training plan for each role.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_2.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Acquire or create training for each role; acquired training may need to be customized for the organization.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_2.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Measure outcome performance to identify areas where changes to training may be beneficial.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_2.

controls.title: Obtain upper management or authorizing official commitment to secure development, and convey that commitment to all with development-related roles and responsibilities.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Appoint a single leader or leadership team to be responsible for the entire secure software development process, including being accountable for releasing software to production and delegating responsibilities as appropriate.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_3.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Increase authorizing officials’ awareness of the risks of developing software without integrating security throughout the development life cycle and the risk mitigation provided by secure development practices.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_3.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Assist upper management in incorporating secure development support into their communications with personnel with development-related roles and responsibilities.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_3.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Educate all personnel with development-related roles and responsibilities on upper management’s commitment to secure development and the importance of secure development to the organization.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_2_3.

groups.title: PO_3
groups.id: Implement Supporting Toolchains

controls.title: Specify which tools or tool types must or should be included in each toolchain to mitigate identified risks, as well as how the toolchain components are to be integrated with each other.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Identify security tools to integrate into the developer toolchain.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_1.

parts.name: Example 3

parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_1.

parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_1.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Use automated technology for toolchain management and orchestration.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_1.

parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_2.

parts.title: Implement the technologies and processes needed for reproducible builds.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_2.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Update, upgrade, or replace tools as needed to address tool vulnerabilities or add new tool capabilities.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_2.

parts.name: Example 6
parts.title: Continuously monitor tools and tool logs for potential operational and security issues, including policy violations and anomalous behavior.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_2.

parts.name: Example 7
parts.title: Regularly verify the integrity and check the provenance of each tool to identify potential problems.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_2.

controls.title: Configure tools to generate artifacts  of their support of secure software development practices as defined by the organization.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Use existing tooling (e.g., workflow tracking, issue tracking, value stream mapping) to create an audit trail of the secure development-related actions that are performed for continuous improvement purposes.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_3.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Determine how often the collected information should be audited, and implement the necessary processes.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_3.

parts.title: Establish and enforce security and retention policies for artifact data.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_3.

parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_3_3.

groups.title: PO_4
groups.id: Define and Use Criteria for Software Security Checks

controls.title: Define criteria for software security checks and track throughout the SDLC.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Ensure that the criteria adequately indicate how effectively security risk is being managed.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Define key performance indicators (KPIs), key risk indicators (KRIs), vulnerability severity scores, and other measures for software security.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_1.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Add software security criteria to existing checks (e.g., the Definition of Done in agile SDLC methodologies).
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_1.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Review the artifacts generated as part of the software development workflow system to determine if they meet the criteria.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_1.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Record security check approvals, rejections, and exception requests as part of the workflow and tracking system.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_1.

parts.name: Example 6
parts.title: Analyze collected data in the context of the security successes and failures of each development project, and use the results to improve the SDLC.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_1.

controls.title: Implement processes, mechanisms, etc. to gather and safeguard the necessary information in support of the criteria.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Use the toolchain to automatically gather information that informs security decision-making.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_2.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Deploy additional tools if needed to support the generation and collection of information supporting the criteria.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_2.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Automate decision-making processes utilizing the criteria, and periodically review these processes.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_2.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Only allow authorized personnel to access the gathered information, and prevent any alteration or deletion of the information.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_4_2.

groups.title: PO_5
groups.id: Implement and Maintain Secure Environments for Software Development

controls.title: Separate and protect each environment involved in software development.

props.name: SCAGILE
props.value: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 11

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Use multi-factor, risk-based authentication and conditional access for each environment.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Use network segmentation and access controls to separate the environments from each other and from production environments, and to separate components from each other within each non-production environment, in order to reduce attack surfaces and attackers’ lateral movement and privilege/access escalation.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Enforce authentication and tightly restrict connections entering and exiting each software development environment, including minimizing access to the internet to only what is necessary.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Minimize direct human access to toolchain systems, such as build services. Continuously monitor and audit all access attempts and all use of privileged access.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Minimize the use of production-environment software and services from non-production environments.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 6
parts.title: Regularly log, monitor, and audit trust relationships for authorization and access between the environments and between the components within each environment.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 7
parts.title: Continuously log and monitor operations and alerts across all components of the development environment to detect, respond, and recover from attempted and actual cyber incidents.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 8
parts.title: Configure security controls and other tools involved in separating and protecting the environments to generate artifacts for their activities.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 9
parts.title: Continuously monitor all software deployed in each environment for new vulnerabilities, and respond to vulnerabilities appropriately following a risk-based approach.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

parts.name: Example 10
parts.title: Configure and implement measures to secure the environments’ hosting infrastructures following a zero trust architecture.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_1.

controls.title: Secure and harden development endpoints (i.e., endpoints for software designers, developers, testers, builders, etc.) to perform development-related tasks using a risk-based approach.

props.name: NISTCSF
props.value: PR.AC-4, PR.AC-7, PR.IP-1, PR.IP-3, PR.IP-12, PR.PT-1, PR.PT-3, DE.CM

props.name: SCAGILE
props.value: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 11

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Configure each development endpoint based on approved hardening guides, checklists, etc.; for example, enable FIPS-compliant encryption of all sensitive data at rest and in transit.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_2.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Configure each development endpoint and the development resources to provide the least functionality needed by users and services and to enforce the principle of least privilege.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_2.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Continuously monitor the security posture of all development endpoints, including monitoring and auditing all use of privileged access.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_2.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Configure security controls and other tools involved in securing and hardening development endpoints to generate artifacts for their activities.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_2.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Require multi-factor authentication for all access to development endpoints and development resources.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_2.

parts.name: Example 6
parts.title: Provide dedicated development endpoints on non-production networks for performing all development-related tasks. Provide separate endpoints on production networks for all other tasks.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_2.

parts.name: Example 7
parts.title: Configure each development endpoint following a zero trust architecture.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PO_5_2.

groups.title: PS_1
groups.id: Protect All Forms of Code from Unauthorized Access and Tampering

controls.title: Store all forms of code – including source code, executable code, and configuration-as-code –  based on the principle of least privilege so that only authorized personnel, tools, services, etc. have access.

props.name: CNCFSSCP
props.value: Securing the Source Code—Verification, Automation, Controlled Environments, Secure Authentication; Securing Materials—Automation

props.name: SCSIC
props.value: Vendor Software Delivery Integrity Controls, Vendor Software Development Integrity Controls

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Store all source code and configuration-as-code in a code repository, and restrict access to it based on the nature of the code. For example, open-source code intended for public access may need its integrity and availability protected; other code may also need its confidentiality protected.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_1_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Use version control features of the repository to track all changes made to the code with accountability to the individual account.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_1_1.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Use commit signing for code repositories.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_1_1.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Have the code owner review and approve all changes made to the code by others.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_1_1.

parts.name: Example 5
parts.title: Use code signing  to help protect the integrity of executables.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_1_1.

parts.name: Example 6
parts.title: Use cryptography (e.g., cryptographic hashes) to help protect file integrity.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_1_1.

groups.title: PS_2
groups.id: Provide a Mechanism for Verifying Software Release Integrity

controls.title: Make software integrity verification information available to software acquirers.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Post cryptographic hashes for release files on a well-secured website.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_2_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Use an established certificate authority for code signing so that consumers’ operating systems or other tools and services can confirm the validity of signatures before use.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_2_1.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Periodically review the code signing processes, including certificate renewal, rotation, revocation, and protection.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_2_1.

groups.title: PS_3
groups.id: Archive and Protect Each Software Release

controls.title: Securely archive the necessary files and supporting data (e.g., integrity verification information, provenance data) to be retained for each software release.

props.name: CNCFSSCP
props.value: Securing Artefacts—Automation, Controlled Environments, Encryption; Securing Deployments—Verification

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Store the release files, associated images, etc. in repositories following the organization’s established policy. Allow read-only access to them by necessary personnel and no access by anyone else.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_3_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Store and protect release integrity verification information and provenance data, such as by keeping it in a separate location from the release files or by signing the data.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_3_1.

controls.title: Collect, safeguard, maintain, and share provenance data for all components of each software release (e.g., in a software bill of materials [SBOM]).

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Make the provenance data available to software acquirers in accordance with the organization’s policies, preferably using standards-based formats.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_3_2.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Make the provenance data available to the organization’s operations and response teams to aid them in mitigating software vulnerabilities.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_3_2.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Protect the integrity of provenance data, and provide a way for recipients to verify provenance data integrity.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_3_2.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Update the provenance data every time any of the software’s components are updated.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PS_3_2.

groups.title: PW_1
groups.id: Design Software to Meet Security Requirements and Mitigate Security Risks

controls.title: Use forms of risk modeling – such as threat modeling, attack modeling, or attack surface mapping – to help assess the security risk for the software.

props.name: SCAGILE
props.value: Tasks Requiring the Help of Security Experts 3

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Train the development team (security champions, in particular) or collaborate with a risk modeling expert to create models and analyze how to use a risk-based approach to communicate the risks and determine how to address them, including implementing mitigations.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PW_1_1.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Perform more rigorous assessments for high-risk areas, such as protecting sensitive data and safeguarding identification, authentication, and access control, including credential management.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PW_1_1.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Review vulnerability reports and statistics for previous software to inform the security risk assessment.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PW_1_1.

parts.name: Example 4
parts.title: Use data classification methods to identify and characterize each type of data that the software will interact with.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PW_1_1.

controls.title: Track and maintain the software’s security requirements, risks, and design decisions.

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Record the response to each risk, including how mitigations are to be achieved and what the rationales are for any approved exceptions to the security requirements. Add any mitigations to the software’s security requirements.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PW_1_2.

parts.name: Example 2
parts.title: Maintain records of design decisions, risk responses, and approved exceptions that can be used for auditing and maintenance purposes throughout the rest of the software life cycle.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PW_1_2.

parts.name: Example 3
parts.title: Periodically re-evaluate all approved exceptions to the security requirements, and implement changes as needed.
parts.prose: This is an example implementation of the control PW_1_2.

controls.title: Where appropriate, build in support for using standardized security features and services (e.g., enabling software to integrate with existing log management, identity management, access control, and vulnerability management systems) instead of creating proprietary implementations of security features and services. [Formerly PW.4.3]

props.name: SCFPSSD
props.value: Standardize Identity and Access Management; Establish Log Requirements and Audit Practices

parts.name: Example 1
parts.title: Maintain one or more software repositories of modules for supporting standardized security features and services.
